content.webTitle: 'I'll make a sign and hold it up': Isobelle Carmody takes her activism to the streets

fields.headline: 'I'll make a sign and hold it up': Isobelle Carmody takes her activism to the streets
fields.bodyText: “I’ve always thought of myself as a bit of a coward,” says Isobelle Carmody. “A lot of my writing is about courage – learning what courage is, trying to find our own courage, that sort of thing – because I didn’t feel very brave at all when I was young.” It’s a surprising admission from the acclaimed writer. For three decades now, Carmody has been one of Australia’s most beloved fantasy authors, for children and adults alike. At just 14 she began work on her first book, Obernewtyn, which was published in 1987 and spawned the fantasy series of the same name. Her novel The Gathering was a high school favourite for many Australian teens and won her both the 1993 Children’s Literature Peace prize and the 1994 CBCA Book of the Year award. But Carmody has also earned a reputation for bravery thanks to her vocal activism against the Australian government’s offshore processing of refugees. In person, Carmody is articulate and outgoing, with vibrant red hair and silver jewellery. She sits across the table from me at a local cafe and gestures expressively with her hands as she talks. Beside us, resting against the table leg for our fellow customers to read, is her latest protest sign. Carmody is deeply passionate about a number of causes, among them China’s bile bears. But it is the plight of the refugees on Nauru and Manus Island that holds most of her attention and her heart. She hasn’t always been as much of an activist as she is now. “I cared about these things, I was informed, and it seemed that I was doing a lot, so it never occurred to me that I should do anything more,” she tells Guardian Australia. “A lot of writers feel the way I do, but because they write about it they give themselves a pass on doing anything more, and I was one of those people.” Perhaps one of the first and most important things to change was Carmody’s perception of herself. Her partner, Jan, is Czech, and grew up in Europe under communism. Even before Carmody began her protest action, Jan saw a much braver person in her than she was willing to admit. “My partner once told me that when you grow up under communism, you look at people differently,” Carmody says. She was afraid she might have been what Jan calls a “grey person”: “someone who didn’t collaborate, but did nothing to resist.” Some time later, in 2016, Carmody was making dinner for her family when she learnt about Baby Asha, the child born to asylum seeker parents, who had been transported from Nauru to Lady Cilento Children’s hospital in Brisbane for treatment. The doctors at the hospital were refusing to discharge her to prevent her being sent back to the island. Protesters kept a vigil outside the hospital, blockading exits and inspecting cars leaving the building to ensure the child was not removed. Dropping everything and leaving her family to fend for themselves, Carmody joined them. “That was the beginning for me, at Lady Cilento,” says Carmody. “It was so special. It had a specific, short-term goal – it was a child we were protecting, medical staff were validating what we were doing – everything was right about it. And we were successful. I’ve met many, many people since then at marches and events who say the same thing, that this was the inciting incident for them too.” After the Lady Cilento protest, Carmody wrote letters and signed petitions, “all that stuff you do as a moderate-level activist.” She also chatted online with many of the young people in the facilities. Then the closure of the Manus Island facility was announced. As she was preparing for a research trip to the US, Carmody watched her social media feeds in horror as water, electricity, food and medical supplies to the facility were cut off. “I thought, I’m not just going to just get on with my books while that’s happening to human beings at the behest of my government. I’m going to make a sign, and I’m going to stand and hold it up in Oregon. And that’s what I did, day after day.” The first time she stood out in the street with her sign, her hands and knees shook. “I was actually frightened of standing there with that sign. Because people look at you and you’re just so naked in that gaze,” she says. But she soon found an almost meditative aspect to standing alone for an hour at a time each day. “There’s an introspection in standing. It does make me know myself very well.” Anxiety wasn’t the only obstacle: she also had two fractured knees from a skiing accident, and would limp to her location for the day and prop herself up when she got there. Nevertheless, she says, there is an energy that comes from activism. “Standing up for something you believe in strengthens you and it makes you brave. It gives you the best kind of power.” The sign that rests by our table as we talk has been the subject of many glances, most of them friendly. Carmody updates and rewrites her signs regularly. The phrase “I am watching” often features. Carmody says it is a central part of her message. “It’s about keeping my eyes on something the government doesn’t want you to see and I want them to know that I won’t look away.” She doesn’t shout slogans at passersby; her protest is mostly silent. “I look in the faces and meet the eyes of the people passing. Not in a confronting way, but I like to meet each person’s eyes as they pass.” It’s important to listen, she says. “People say unthinkable things. I try not to react. It’s not in my nature to be angry. It’s in my nature to communicate. It’s much harder for someone to hate you if you are willing to listen to them.” She is also active online. “The standing is only one part … the blog posts and social media go much wider.” As a result, there are now people all over Australia who are standing with their own signs because they have seen Carmody doing it, either online or in person. Carmody is aware that speaking out makes her a target; she takes precautions for her safety on the street and says she has been lucky so far. Her writing, though, has suffered. “This has had a definite impact on my life,” she says. “It’s delayed my books over and again. It hasn’t yet destroyed my health; it might destroy my bank balance, but I don’t care.” She has considered writing about the subject, but says: “A lot of this is too close right now. The alchemy of my writing is very slow, it happens over a long period. It’s a very slow evolution.” She is also aware of her own limits. “There are lots of people out there doing small things that create a ripple effect. I’m a person who is prepared to make an effort as often and as much as I can. I am one of those people and that’s what I can do,” she says. Approached to run for the Senate, her answer was simple: “That’s not what I can do.” Carmody was recently issued a fine by Brisbane City council for her one-woman protest. Given the choice to contest the fine, she insists that the issue is not whether or not she can avoid paying it but her right to free speech. “I am not saying that I didn’t do it, I am saying that I have the right to do it. And nobody has the right to get in the way of my free speech. We have to challenge that and we have to push back,” she says. But Carmody isn’t just out there on the street to defend Australia’s freedom of speech; she hopes to galvanise people. “I want people to act, I want people to realise there’s virtue in action and there’s empowerment. I get as much from it as I give. If you’re considering crossing that Rubicon, know this – once you stand up, you’ll never sit down again. A child’s life for our safety? No, that price is too high.”
